quiz.title: Chemistry: Unit 3 Quiz 1
quiz.subtitle: 3.1: History of the Atom: Dalton, Thomson, Rutherford
quiz.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: John Dalton's atomic theory was based on the idea that atoms are:
options: Mostly empty space with a central nucleus.
Made of cloud-like regions of probability.
questions.explanation: Dalton viewed the atom as the smallest unit of matter—a solid, indivisible 'billiard ball' that could not be broken down further.

questions.question: J.J. Thomson discovered the electron using which experimental tool?
questions.explanation: Thomson observed that rays in the tube were deflected by magnetic and electric fields, proving atoms contained negatively charged particles.

questions.question: Rutherford’s Gold Foil experiment led to the discovery of the:
questions.explanation: Because a few alpha particles bounced back, Rutherford concluded that atoms must have a small, dense, positively charged center.

questions.question: Which scientist proposed the 'Plum Pudding' model of the atom?
questions.explanation: Thomson suggested the atom was a sphere of positive charge with negative electrons embedded in it, like raisins in pudding.

questions.question: What surprising observation did Rutherford make during the Gold Foil experiment?
options: Most alpha particles passed straight through the foil.
All alpha particles were absorbed by the foil.
The gold foil turned into lead.
questions.explanation: This observation proved that the atom is mostly empty space, rather than a solid mass.

questions.question: According to Dalton’s theory, all atoms of a specific element are:
options: Able to change into other elements.
Differentiated by their number of electrons.
questions.explanation: Dalton believed all atoms of the same element were exactly alike, though we now know isotopes mean they can have different masses.

questions.question: Thomson’s discovery of the electron proved that the atom was actually:
questions.explanation: By finding the electron, Thomson proved that the atom was made of even smaller pieces, contradicting Dalton's 'indivisible' claim.

questions.question: Rutherford concluded that the nucleus must have a positive charge because it:
options: Repelled the positively charged alpha particles.
Attracted the negatively charged alpha particles.
Emitted blue light during the experiment.
questions.explanation: Since 'like charges repel,' the deflection of positive alpha particles indicated a positive charge in the center of the atom.

questions.question: Democritus was an ancient Greek philosopher who first used the term 'atomos,' which means:
questions.explanation: Democritus hypothesized that matter could only be divided so many times until you reached a piece that was 'uncuttable' (atomos).

questions.question: Which of Dalton's original postulates is now known to be incorrect due to the discovery of isotopes?
options: Atoms of the same element are identical in mass.
Chemical reactions involve the rearrangement of atoms.
All matter is composed of atoms.
questions.explanation: We now know that isotopes of the same element have different numbers of neutrons, and therefore, different masses.
